REPL-108 Player

Subtask Em andamento Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 08/ago/24 12:38 PM 29/out/24 11:18 AM 12/out/24 7:48 PM           0 1   Domain:
(pkg/domain/replay/entities/player.go)


PlayerAPI (use case overview):
*Refinement Notes:*

{noformat} // 2) Dispatch para Channels de Persistencia de dados das entidades apos cada round
// Obs: Importante ser no RoundEnd e também informar o estado no payload do evento para manter a collection da entidade sincronizada
// 2.0 IMPL. ENTITIES
// 2.1 IMPL. MULTIPLEX LOGIC ON HANDLER IN ORDER TO ROUTE FROM RECEIVED EVENT CHANNEL TO AN INBOUND COMMAND PORT
// - Query existing data for existence-check
// - Create or Update with new data
// - Dispatch additional events
// (ie:
// - indexation or external integration (e.g.: notification, workflow status change, etc)
// - player validation (*) (TODO: verificar o que pode ser validado aqui, e.g.: NetworkID valido, VAC etc)
// - stats processing, - badge (first match/round/frag etc))
//
// 2.2 MAP OUTBOUND COMMAND PORT ON CONTAINER (INFRASTRUCTURE LAYER, IoC) WITH THE INSTANCE CONSTRUCTOR (CREATIONAL FACTORY OR METHOD),
// FOR THE CONCRETE DATABASE ADAPTER (INHERIT FROM GENERIC REPO AT INFRASTRUCTURE LAYER),
// e.g.: replay_out.PlayerMetadataWriter (command layer, outbound port) <------Singleton------- MongoDBPlayerRepository
// replay_out.PlayerMetadataReader (query layer, outbound port) <-----/
//
//
// 2.3 MAP INBOUND COMMAND PORT ON CONTAINER IN (INFRASTRUCTURE LAYER, IoC) IN ORDER TO UPSERT THE RECEIVED ENTITY STATE TO MONGODB COLLECTION (IMPL. AND USE ENTITY X COLL. MAPPING ON INFRASTRUCTURE LAYER)
// e.g.: replay_in.CreateOrUpdatePlayerCommand (command layer, inbound port) <---Singleton--- replay_in.CreateOrUpdatePlayerUseCase (command layer, driving adapter)
// (depends on outbound ports){noformat} 		08/ago/24 12:38 PM Em andamento R/W Essential Round Metadata and computed Statistics

REPL-99 Integration Tests (Search)

Subtask Em andamento Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/ago/24 3:02 PM   07/ago/24 3:02 PM           0 1   07/ago/24 3:02 PM Em andamento Generic Search API

Replay API REPL-104

REPL-99 [ResourceOwner] Fanout Request/Context Credentials, Roles and Claims to Search Payload

Subtask Ready / Prioritized Medium Não resolvido(s) psavelis Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/ago/24 12:32 PM 12/out/24 9:48 PM 07/ago/24 2:47 PM           0 1   Propagate current context’s visibility access to search parameters.

*Instructions:*
ReplayAPI already implements a custom-tailored Multi-Tenant, Authorization Framework, specially for LeetGaming ecosystem, which is supports the common.Search and is supported on MongoDB implementation for all repositories. (Refer to {{MongoDBRepository[iam_entity.RIDToken]}} for concrete examples of Authorization and Multi-Tenancy)

Change/Snippet of domain/search.go (no need to change, already implemented):

{noformat}func NewSearchByAggregation(ctx context.Context, aggregationParams []SearchAggregation, resultOptions SearchResultOptions, audienceLevel IntendedAudienceKey) Search {
visibility := SearchVisibilityOptions{
RequestSource: GetResourceOwner(ctx),
IntendedAudience: audienceLevel,
}

if resultOptions.Limit == 0 {
resultOptions.Limit = DefaultPageSize
}

return Search{
SearchParams: aggregationParams,
ResultOptions: resultOptions,
VisibilityOptions: visibility,
}
}{noformat}



Context Parameters (always available, thanks to the ResourceOwner middleware and RID implementation):


{noformat} // Tenancy
TenantIDKey ContextKey = "tenantID"
ClientIDKey ContextKey = "clientID"
GroupIDKey ContextKey = "groupID"
UserIDKey ContextKey = "userID"

// Example Parameters
RequestIDKey ContextKey = "request"
GameIDParamKey ContextKey = "game_id"
MatchIDParamKey ContextKey = "match_id"{noformat} 		07/ago/24 12:32 PM Em andamento Generic Search API
0|i001c7: Developers

Replay API REPL-102

REPL-99 [IoC] Map Type Dependencies on Container

Subtask Em andamento Medium Não resolvido(s) psavelis Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 06/ago/24 3:36 AM   07/ago/24 3:02 PM           0 1   h3. Multiplexer Dependency Setup (container/DI)


Configure component lifecycle and resolution for generic repositories (e.g.: {{common.Searchable[replay_entity.Badge]}} as {{BadgeReader}} ) for resolving dependencies of the core search component {{SearchableResourceMultiplexer}} (“Dictionary” implementation for routing resources to it’s corresponding {{SearchController[T any]}} instance)

*Architectural Instructions:*

*IOC:*
As ReplayAPI applies loose coupling, we’ve set up a dedicated module for dependency injection under {{/src/pkg/infra/ioc}}

*Hexagonal Architecture (Ports And Adapters):*
ReplayAPI is designed to work with inbound ports ("driving” adapters, or entry points, such as MobileApp, API or CommandLine Interface) and outbound ports (“driven”adapters, such as repositories or clients to third-party services or external data).

A Searchable is an interface of Outbound Port (or Output Port, which is the same but appears in some references with this alternative naming).

A Port is an interface with very small granularity.
An Adapter (in the context of “Ports and Adapters”) is the concrete implementation of a Port.

In the case of {{common.Searchable[replay_entity.Badge]}}, it represents a interface definition of a Driven component (an Outbound Port, that access data from outside the application) which requires implementation of it’s defined interface into a Adapter (read “Repository” – this is the bad part of hexagonal which ambiguates the “Adapter” *actor* *layer* with our well known “Adapter” *design* *pattern*).

*MongoDB Adapter Implementation for BadgeReader:*

As ReplayAPI already implemented as custom-tailored micro orm for the solution, use the builder {{MongoDBRepositoryBuilder[T common.BaseEntity]}} to create the corresponding instance and Register in the container as a Right/Output/Outbound/Driven adapter for {{BadgeReader}}


*Same for the other core entities:*

* GameEvent
* Match √
* Player
* ReplayFile
* Team

 06/ago/24 3:36 AM Em andamento Generic Search API
0|i001br: Developers

Replay API REPL-97

EPIC: "Challenge" Support (BugReport's Upstream Domain)

Epic Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Leet Gaming Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 27/jul/24 4:43 PM   27/jul/24 4:43 PM           0 0   *Summary:* Implement "Challenge" Module for Glitch/Bug Reporting / Analysis

*Description:*

As CS2 evolves, it's crucial to have a mechanism for addressing game-breaking glitches or bugs that may occur during +*tournament*+ matches. This feature request proposes the implementation of a "Challenge" module within the ReplayAPI to handle such situations, as this “fiction” story below generated by AI:

{color:#6554c0}*_The Decisive 15th Round (generated by Gemini)_*{color}

{quote}{color:#6554c0}_The tension was palpable. It was the 15th round of a crucial match in the ESL Pro League. "FaZe Clan" and "Natus Vincere" were locked in an intense battle, with the score tied at 7-7. Every round mattered, every decision could swing the momentum._{color}

{color:#6554c0}_As the round began, "s1mple," Na`Vi's star AWPer, peeked out from "A-Long" on Mirage. He caught a glimpse of "broky," FaZe's own sniper, adjusting his position at "Palace." A split-second decision, a flick of the wrist, and a shot rang out._{color}

{color:#6554c0}_But something was amiss. The kill feed showed "broky" had been eliminated, yet he was still visible on the screen,seemingly oblivious to the fatal shot. A collective gasp rose from the audience, both online and in the arena. A game-breaking bug had reared its ugly head at the worst possible time._{color}

{color:#6554c0}*_The Chaos Unfolds_*{color}

{color:#6554c0}_The casters scrambled to make sense of the situation. "Is this real? Did 's1mple' just kill a ghost?" one commentator exclaimed. The players themselves were confused. "broky" continued playing, even planting the bomb at "A-Site" while his spectral form roamed the map._{color}

{color:#6554c0}_Na`Vi, unaware of the bug's implications, hesitated. Should they push the site, risking a surprise flank from a "dead" player? Or should they play it safe, allowing the bomb to explode and potentially losing the round?_{color}

{color:#6554c0}_Meanwhile, FaZe Clan, recognizing the advantage the bug had given them, exploited the situation. The "ghost" of "broky" distracted Na`Vi, drawing their attention away from the real "broky" who was calmly defusing the bomb._{color}

{color:#6554c0}*_The Aftermath_*{color}

{color:#6554c0}_Na`Vi lost the round and, subsequently, the match. The controversy surrounding the bugged round overshadowed their valiant efforts throughout the game. Post-match discussions erupted online, with fans and analysts debating the fairness of the outcome._{color}

{color:#6554c0}_The incident highlighted a critical flaw in the competitive landscape of CS2: the lack of a reliable pause and review system for dealing with game-breaking bugs. If a pause feature had been available, the referees could have analyzed the situation, potentially restarting the round and ensuring a fair outcome for both teams._{color}

{color:#6554c0}*_The Call for Change_*{color}

{color:#6554c0}_The "ghost broky" incident became a rallying cry for change within the CS2 community. Players, coaches, and fans alike demanded a system that could address such critical bugs in real time._{color}

{color:#6554c0}_Eventually, Valve responded by implementing a pause and review feature in CS2. Teams were now able to request a pause if they suspected a bug had significantly impacted the round. This allowed referees to review the gameplay, determine the extent of the bug's influence, and decide on a course of action – whether to restart the round, adjust the score, or continue play._{color}{quote}

*Goals:*

* {color:#36b37e}*Provide a way for team managers or players to request a pause and review of a round due to a suspected bug or glitch.*{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Enable referees/admins to analyze the reported incident using ReplayAPI's tools.*{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Facilitate a voting mechanism (optional/TBD) among players to determine whether the round should be restarted.*{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Log detailed information about the glitch, including tick range, player actions, and potential impact on the round outcome.*{color}

*Draft Requirements (IF Considering Possible Feature Support**):*

* *As a team manager,* I want to be able to pause the match and request a review if I believe a bug has occurred that significantly impacts the round's fairness.
* *As a player,* I want the ability to flag potential glitches and provide information to the referee for review.
* *As a referee,* I want to be able to access a detailed replay of the round, including *tick-by-tick* analysis, to determine if a bug has occurred and how it has affected the game.
* *As a tournament organizer,* I want a system that ensures fair play and resolves game-breaking bugs in a transparent and timely manner.

*Draft Mechanics*

* Upon challenge, the match is paused, and a notification is sent to the referee/admin.
* Referees/admins can review the reported incident using ReplayAPI's existing analysis tools.
* The system allows for (optional/TO BE DEFINED) player voting on whether to restart the round.
* A "Glitch Details" model is created to store:
** MatchID
** RoundNumber
** TickRange
** Player Initiating Challenge (if applicable)
** Description of the Glitch
** Type/Etc
** Referee Decision (restart, adjust score, continue play, tbd…)
* Glitch details are logged for future analysis and bug fixing.

*Task Breakdown:*

# *Database Schema Design:*
#* Create "Glitch Details" model in the database.
# *Backend API Implementation:*
#* Add endpoints for challenge requests, referee actions, and voting.
#* Implement logic to handle challenges and update the game state accordingly.

By addressing this issue, the ReplayAPI can become an even more valuable tool for ensuring fair play and maintaining the competitive integrity of CS2. 		API, Analytics, Backend, CS:GO/CS:2, Data, GameEvent 27/jul/24 4:43 PM Em andamento purple
0|i0017b: Nenhum

* Efficiency
** Draft:
** {noformat}type EfficiencyState = int

const (
EFStateScore EfficiencyState = iota
EFStateConcede
EFStateTie
EFStateInvalid
)

type StatEfficiencyUnit struct {
Total uint32
Efficiency float64
State EfficiencyState
// PriorStates []EfficiencyState
ScoreBreakdown map[EfficiencyState]float64
TendencyBreakdown map[EfficiencyState]float64

// Optional Diff
// PriorState EfficiencyState
// EfficiencyDifference float64

// Optional chaining
// PriorEfficiency *StatEfficiencyUnit
// Forecast *StatEfficiencyUnit
}{noformat} 		12/jul/24 3:35 PM Em andamento [SDK][gRPC] Stats Schema (Protobuff/Sendtables)

REPL-76 CSEconomyStats

Subtask Em andamento Medium Não resolvido(s) Pedro Savelis Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 12/jul/24 3:32 PM   11/out/24 4:54 AM           0 1   12/jul/24 3:32 PM Em andamento [SDK][gRPC] Stats Schema (Protobuff/Sendtables)

Replay API REPL-76

[SDK][gRPC] Stats Schema (Protobuff/Sendtables)

Tarefa Ready / Prioritized Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 12/jul/24 3:32 PM 29/out/24 11:05 AM 12/out/24 9:47 PM           0 1   REPL-77, REPL-78, REPL-79, REPL-80, REPL-82, REPL-83, REPL-84, REPL-85, REPL-86, REPL-87, REPL-88, REPL-89, REPL-90, REPL-91, REPL-92, REPL-93, REPL-94, REPL-95, REPL-96 h1. DRAFT (SDK Models/Schema + Optimization => Reduce Bandwidth of intense data by applying Send-table pattern through gRPC using Protobuff schemas)

{color:#6554c0}*Define Protobuf Schemas (.proto Files)*{color}

# Create {{.proto}} files to define the structure of your messages (entities) for gRPC communication. This is where we’ll translate our Go structs into Protobuf definitions. Here's an example for {{CSEconomyStats}} entity:

{noformat}Protocol Buffers{noformat}

{noformat}syntax = "proto3";

package replay_api;

// Represents the economic state of a team in a round.
enum CSEconomyState {
UNDEFINED = 0;
PISTOL_ROUND = 1;
FULL_BUY = 2;
FULL_BUY_SECOND = 3;
HALF_BUY = 4;
// ... (rest of the CSEconomyState enum and props)
}

// Totalizer for economic values will also become SENDTABLEs!!
message CSEconomyTotalizer {
int32 total = 1;
int32 avg = 2;
int32 median = 3;
int32 min = 4;
int32 max = 5;
}

// Return on investment (ROI) for economic items. -- Same thing!
message CSEconomyROI {
int32 direct_frags = 1;
int32 assistance_frags = 2;
int32 entry_frags = 3;
int32 exit_frags = 4;
int32 trade_frags = 5;
}

// Statistics for a specific economic item.
message CSEconomyItemStats {
int32 count = 1;
CSEconomyTotalizer price = 2;
CSEconomyROI frags = 3;
CSEconomyTotalizer damage = 4;
CSEconomyTotalizer reward = 5;
}

// Comprehensive economic statistics for a CS:GO round or match.
message CSEconomyStats {
CSEconomyState state = 1;
int32 total_spend = 2;
// ... (rest of the fields)
}
{noformat}

h1. 2. Generate Go Code from Protobuf Schemas

Use the Protobuf compiler ({{protoc}}) to generate Go code from our {{.proto}} files. This will create Go structs that correspond to your Protobuf messages.

{noformat}Bash{noformat}

{noformat}protoc --go_out=. --go_opt=paths=source_relative \
--go-grpc_out=. --go-grpc_opt=paths=source_relative \
replay_api_schema.proto
{noformat}

# Implement gRPC Service
# *Define Service:* Create a gRPC service definition ({{.proto}}) that specifies the methods for transmitting your game data.
{noformat}Protocol Buffers{noformat}
{noformat}service GameDataService {
rpc GetRoundEconomyStats (RoundRequest) returns (CSEconomyStats) {}
// ... other methods for player stats, trajectories, etc.
}
{noformat}
# *Implement the Service:* In our Go server, implement the methods defined in the gRPC service. These methods will retrieve the necessary data from your analysis engine or database and package it into the generated Protobuf messages.
# *Run gRPC Server:* Start the replay-api (go) with gRPC driving adapter to listen for incoming requests.
# Send Data over gRPC

In our replay api Go code (e.g., replay demo parser handler), use the generated gRPC client to send the Protobuf messages {color:#6554c0}to {color}{color:#6554c0}*gRPC endpoint (NOT REST, GRPC (INTERNAL UDP))*{color}. This will efficiently transfer the structured data over the network.

*Example gRPC Client Code:*

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}// ... in Go handler
func EconomyEvent(p dem.Parser, matchContext *state.CS2MatchContext, out chan replay_entity.GameEvent) func(e evt.RoundFreezetimeEnd) {
return func(event evt.RoundFreezetimeEnd) {
// ... our existing logic
economyStats := &cs_entity.CSEconomyStats{
State: cs_entity.CSEconomyState_FULL_BUY, // Example
// ... set other fields
}

// Send economyStats to the gRPC server using the generated client
_, err := gameDataClient.GetRoundEconomyStats(ctx, &replay_sdk.RoundRequest{RoundId: roundIndex})
if err != nil {
// Handle error
}
}
}
{noformat}

h1. {color:#6554c0}*Best Practices*{color}{color:#ff5630} {color}*for*{color:#ff5630} ****OPTIMIZATION***:*{color}

* {color:#6554c0}*Compression*{color}*:* Use gRPC's built-in compression (e.g., gzip) to reduce message size.
* {color:#6554c0}*Caching*{color}*:* Cache frequently requested data on the server-side.
* {color:#6554c0}*Stream*{color} *Data:* If have large amounts of data (e.g., trajectories), consider using gRPC streaming to send it in chunks.
* *Message Structure:* Design Protobuf messages to be as compact as possible. {color:#6554c0}*Avoid unnecessary nesting or fields.*{color} 		API, Analytics, Backend, CS:GO/CS:2, Component, Data, Filter, Filtering, GameEvent, Generics, Pagination, ReplayAPI, Search, replay-api 12/jul/24 3:32 PM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development
0|i0008t:i Nenhum
Replay API REPL-75

[PARSER] Map-Specific Player Profiles Stats

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 01/jul/24 11:39 PM   01/jul/24 11:42 PM           0 1   *Core Concept:*

Instead of a single, generalized player report, generate _map-specific player profiles_ that highlight the variations in a player's strengths, weaknesses, and tendencies based on the map they're playing. This allows for a more granular understanding of how a player adapts to different environments and strategic demands.

*Structure of the Map-Specific Player Profile:*

# *Map Overview:*
#* Map Name and Image: Visual representation for quick reference.
#* Player Role on this Map: Clearly indicate the primary role the player typically plays (Entry Fragger, Support, Lurker, etc.).
#* Overall Rating: A consolidated rating (e.g., 1-10) that summarizes the player's performance on this map.
# *Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):*
#* Map-Specific Stats:
#** K/D/A (Kills/Deaths/Assists)
#** ADR (Average Damage per Round)
#** KAST (Percentage of rounds with Kill, Assist, Survive, or Trade)
#** HLTV Rating (If available)
#** Impact Rating (A custom metric combining various stats)
#* Role-Specific Stats (Dynamically generated based on the player's role):
#** Entry Fragger: Opening duel success rate, first-kill percentage.
#** Support: Flash assists, grenade effectiveness (damage/kills).
#** AWPer: AWP kills per round, AWP accuracy.
#** Lurker: Flank success rate, impact in late-round situations.
# *Heatmaps and Visualizations:*
#* Heatmap Layers: Show separate heatmaps for:
#** Kills: Where the player gets most of their kills.
#** Deaths: Where the player tends to die.
#** Utility Usage: Grenade throws, smoke placements, etc.
#* 3D Heatmap (R3F): Consider using R3F for a more immersive 3D heatmap overlay on the map model itself.
#* Trajectory Visualization: Show the player's typical movement paths and common angles.
#* Vision Cones: Optionally, visualize areas visible to the player at different times.
# *Round-by-Round Analysis:*
#* Concise Summary: Provide a quick overview of the player's performance in each round (K/D/A, impact highlights).
#* Round Type Filters: Allow filtering by win/loss, side (T/CT), and round outcome (e.g., bomb plant, defuse).
#* Notable Rounds: Automatically highlight exceptional rounds (clutches, multi-kills, significant utility impact).
# *Strategic Insights:*
#* Tendency Analysis: Identify the player's tendencies on specific areas of the map (e.g., aggressive pushes,passive holds).
#* Weakness Exploitation: Suggest areas where the player might be vulnerable based on their death heatmap.
#* Teammate Synergy: Highlight how the player interacts with their teammates on this map (trades, coordinated plays).
# *Comparisons:*
#* Map-to-Map: Allow comparisons between the player's profiles on different maps.
#* Role Comparisons: Compare the player's performance in different roles (if they play multiple roles).
#* Team Comparisons: Compare the player's stats to team averages on the same map.

*Implementation Notes:*

* *ReplayAPI:* Use the ReplayAPI to extract all relevant data (player positions, events, game state, etc.).
* *Data Processing:* Develop custom algorithms to analyze the data and generate map-specific stats and insights.
* *Frontend:* Build the interactive report UI using React, Next.js, and R3F for 3D visualization.
* *Backend (Optional):* If you have complex analysis, consider a backend service (e.g., Python with data science libraries) to handle the heavy lifting.

*Example Output (Summary):*

* *Inferno:* _Aggressive entry fragger, excels at A site executes but struggles on B site defense._
* *Mirage:* _Solid all-around rifler, consistent utility usage for mid control._
* *Nuke:* _Passive AWPer, effective at holding angles but needs to improve on clutch situations._

*Benefits:*

* *Actionable Insights:* Provides coaches with targeted information for improving a player's performance on specific maps.
* {color:#36b37e}*Personalized Training:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Players can focus on areas where they need improvement on each map.{color}
* *Deeper Understanding:* Reveals hidden patterns and tendencies that might not be apparent in general reports.
* *Competitive Edge:* Allows teams to gain a tactical advantage by understanding how opponents play on different maps. 		01/jul/24 11:39 PM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development
0|i00167: Nenhum
Replay API REPL-74

EPIC: User Feature - E2E Encryption (Default: Enabled, Can disable (with user confirmation))

Epic Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 18/jun/24 4:53 PM   18/jun/24 4:53 PM           0 1   h3. Draft:

In order to provide more secure standards to the platform, use of e2e encryption (does not replace authenticator), which requires user to have additional recovery methods.

Replay API REPL-73

[PARSER] Quadtree + CS2MatchQL - Spatial Structure Optimization

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 12/jun/24 1:40 PM   12/jun/24 4:04 PM           0 1   h2. Goals to achieve:

* {color:#36b37e}*Vision Cone Calculations*{color}*:* Quadtrees are essential for determining which players are visible within another player's vision cone. This enables in-depth analysis of peeking angles, awareness, and potential crossfires.
* {color:#36b37e}*Grenade Effectiveness:*{color} Quadtrees help quickly identify which players were affected by a grenade's blast radius. This data is valuable for evaluating grenade throws and their impact on the game.
* {color:#36b37e}*Map Control:*{color} Quadtrees can track which areas of the map are controlled by each team, revealing strategic patterns and vulnerabilities.
* {color:#36b37e}*Heatmaps*{color}*:* By aggregating player position data over time, you can create heatmaps showing areas where players spend the most time, giving insights into popular positions and rotations.
* {color:#36b37e}*Clustering*{color}*:* Quadtrees can identify clusters of players, revealing coordinated movements or potential ambush spots.

Sequence Draft:

!https://mermaid.ink/img/pako:eNqdVk1P4zAQ_SujnIrUpdIec0BCfC2r3aUQuqdeTDJNvSR2sB2WCvHfd-LEjpsmRVoOxPG89zweP0_6HqUywyiONL7UKFK85CxXrFwLoL-KKcNTXjFhYKVRHc4-YFWw3fny9jB0iaVcMjVKu3pFYZZKpqi1HInfsBITwwyuqoz-jyBsNDFS4WHsvmaZUThNdoBbkeHbWBjV7jcrONGlmogvCyYETkWv3jCtR8l269e8mN7VVNBlfYysz_NcYT6e9wPqujCfI66lKpmxa7SQ5uy_nJ35w45heZc8woJVfEHIdIt6EdvBbbbI6Nw1zFZVIVkGzRtseIEnrZTXIL3eISTYPHt0C-4BhLaFS6gArIzhquQGsJmhpZ55Ueg5kDC9zgFNetqtFnCcgncdrdkOW52A4CHEGToxhnYAOQVAN5GWOQQSt_doDPYRkEALVumtNDCrUHGZ8ZQVxe5kUmxgap_HSzcPvDfzABuwreM9Vz79wdRAJTU3XApNGl7vv87-pfE-zJL6qTmfi-TrzyZw_wNsYMQC-1cthm6ILcHtJsQ4Unf_Yrig03UE64GA1YEcx91K8o8d7bMCngM607RXLob26Yy3UbJ0FvONKMD3prUWeECjOFFBYYGvzXVrdcZ4g3SJWivR3AwKY-aJ4ykHXcSn3Duvy3vYQAPSwLqHeQdiY-RPkt9jj-9gv9X5TbR-1VBrLvKxLr7PO_S9XQc2spf6y82WXK8rTPmGU3aM7KQn1Y5urNM8dixBfybnsiKti8a8rJtt68I1NeSgsgFpylICm47FaHPWGkBXhU0JjJ5tLxD0qGMq47VI3ZYyKzFZi-GnKIZzXwJlY51N2-JqYCLzVZJKu06yr-KF_ReMrGOHXnSGp_npHL4nd79OQhHP2O917oi7aOZ0DjvZyn7Gvj0-LhtMRd0Urbm6FuN50TwqkdR4Rr-63huddWS2WOI6immYMfW8jtbig3CMipXsRBrFRtU4j5Ss820Ub1ih6a22Pbz7vdbNfvwDmFGEHg?type=png|width=1904,height=635!

DRAFT Scaling the QuadServer

!https://mermaid.ink/img/pako:eNqNVMGOmzAQ_RXL590eesyhUrRJq5VaKbukvQCHCZ4FtGAi26wSrfbfO9gGG5Jsm0Pk9_ze2PCGeedFJ5CveKngWLH9JpOZ1P3BwWc8NnBe7x4zyei3wbb7XjeYPiR2zQbAvghsc3Z__81yO1AaVWq33ToPZkdY7fYNpUmMQmhTu2YOeHW0HeQ71RWodae8Y8KxaSKt7we0mBgw-Pso6F-lA8EswzzlzUultVsiMZ3C2LgBAwfQ-JnzqQdB15_OHfHi1IVsZn2UAk_BaCFLKlACRT7k5AqgOm-lOHa1NKlFbIS5L0fcH2hqOqFTXjLhPCozkcG3a0BKHF0exR5PBcf2hEUfDhph7Bm5kCw10vCSXKwOxJk6Ju4bSuRWQRuFL-jymhWMthcR3yo4JuBrToHMys5Flzl-dlu9LkuFpY3HYhaI6NaR7OqruKb599M9o-4bE93AEZdXWAqjyH2_ZRKlmA2Qh-TrLzBF9fTzSrdGXeaGRlDPR0eksZ51sk_XB20UFDQ2ztLAie3pRXs5bV9p_P_q88sn2J4oTgnNbCwN88D16jgKou9yarKbcyMS2-P4HW9RtVALGsTvQ4WMmwpbzPiKlgLUa8Yz-UE6oNzoiQu-MqrHO666vqz46gUaTai3U2RTA9299ezHX0UDD2c?type=png|width=1694,height=629!

*Why Use a Quadtree for CS Replay Analysis?*

# *Efficiency for Large Datasets:* CS matches generate a massive amount of data, especially when tracking player and object positions over time. Quadtrees excel at handling large spatial datasets, significantly reducing the time it takes to find objects within a specific region compared to brute-force approaches.
# *Targeted Searches:* Quadtrees allow for targeted searches within specific areas of interest (e.g., bomb sites, chokepoints, vision cones). This is crucial for efficiently identifying events and interactions that occur in specific locations.
# *Dynamic Updates:* Quadtrees can be dynamically updated as players and objects move. This enables real-time analysis and rendering of overlays without having to rebuild the entire data structure from scratch.
# *Reduced Computational Overhead:* By partitioning the map into quadrants, quadtrees reduce the number of distance calculations needed to determine if an object is within a given area. This is particularly beneficial for complex shapes like vision cones or grenade trajectories.
# *Memory Optimization (Optional):* If you're storing large amounts of historical data, quadtrees can be more memory-efficient than storing all object positions in a flat list, especially when objects are clustered together.

*Code Snippet Comparison*

Let's illustrate the performance difference with two approaches to find players within a bombsite area:

*Brute Force Approach*

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}func findPlayersInBombsiteBruteForce(players []*common.Player, bombsiteArea orb.Polygon) []*common.Player {
var playersInBombsite []*common.Player
for _, player := range players {
if bombsiteArea.Contains(player.Position().Point()) {
playersInBombsite = append(playersInBombsite, player)
}
}
return playersInBombsite
}
{noformat}

*Quadtree Approach*

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}// ... Assuming qt is a quadtree containing player data

func findPlayersInBombsiteQuadtree(qt *quadtree.Quadtree, bombsiteArea orb.Polygon) []orb.Pointer {
return qt.Find(func(node *quadtree.Node) []orb.Pointer {
if !node.Bound().Intersects(bombsiteArea.Bound()) {
return nil // No intersection, skip this branch
}
if node.IsLeaf() {
return node.Points() // Return all points (players) in this leaf
}
return node.Nodes() // Continue searching in child nodes
})
}
{noformat}

*Performance Analysis*

* *Brute Force:* The time complexity is O(n), where n is the number of players. It needs to check every player against the bombsite area.
* *Quadtree:* The time complexity is typically O(log n). The quadtree quickly eliminates irrelevant sections of the map, reducing the number of comparisons significantly.

*Benchmark Results (Illustrative)*

||Number of Players||Brute Force (ms)||Quadtree (ms)||Improvement||
|100|0.5|0.01|50x|
|1,000|5|0.1|50x|
|10,000|50|1|50x|

As you can see, the quadtree approach offers a substantial performance advantage, especially when dealing with a large number of players or complex queries.

*Key Takeaways*

* Quadtrees are powerful tools for optimizing spatial queries in CS replay analysis.
* The performance gains are especially noticeable with large datasets and complex queries.
* Quadtrees enable real-time analysis and rendering of overlays with minimal impact on performance.

*Technical Task: LeetReplay Insights - CS2MatchQL with Quadtree Optimization*

*Overview*

This task focuses on building the backend components for LeetReplay Insights, a powerful query and analysis engine for CS demo files. The primary goals are to:

# *Implement CS2MatchQL:* Create a compiler and query engine for the pattern-matching language CS2MatchQL,allowing users to express complex queries about game events, states, and statistics.
# *Quadtree Optimization:* Integrate quadtree data structures to significantly improve the efficiency of spatial queries in CS2MatchQL.

*Functional Requirements*

# *CS2MatchQL Compiler:*
#* *Lexer & Parser:* Tokenize queries and build an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) representation.
#* *Semantic Analysis:* Validate the AST, perform type checking, and resolve references.
#* *Query Planner & Optimizer:* Transform the AST into an efficient execution plan, leveraging quadtree indexing where applicable.
#* *Query Execution Engine:* Traverse the execution plan and fetch relevant data from the underlying demo or database.
#* *Result Formatting:* Return query results in a standardized format (e.g., JSON).
# *Quadtree Integration:*
#* *Data Structure:* Implement a quadtree data structure to store player positions, grenade locations, and other relevant spatial data.
#* *Construction:* Efficiently build the quadtree from demo data at key points in the match (e.g., round start,significant events).
#* *Updating:* Dynamically update the quadtree as players and objects move.
#* *Querying:* Utilize the quadtree for fast spatial queries, filtering events and states based on location and proximity.
# *ReplayAPI Endpoint:*
#* *Query Endpoint:* Create an API endpoint (e.g., {{/api/matches/:matchId/query}}) to accept CS2MatchQL queries and return results.
#* *Authentication/Authorization:* Ensure proper security measures to protect sensitive data and prevent abuse.

*Non-Functional Requirements (Key for Maximizing Value)*

* *Performance:*
** *Query Execution:* Optimize the query engine to execute queries efficiently, especially for large demos and complex patterns.
** *Quadtree Indexing:* Leverage the quadtree to minimize the number of objects that need to be checked during spatial queries.
** *Caching:* Cache query results and intermediate data to avoid redundant calculations.
** *Concurrency:* Design the system to handle concurrent requests and ensure scalability.
* *Accuracy:*
** *Event Data:* Ensure that the parsed demo data is accurate and consistent with the game engine's state.
** *Quadtree Updates:* Keep the quadtree synchronized with the game state to avoid incorrect results.
* *Error Handling:*
** *Query Validation:* Thoroughly validate queries before execution to catch syntax and semantic errors early.
** *Graceful Error Handling:* Provide informative error messages to users in case of invalid queries or unexpected conditions.
* *Extensibility:*
** *Custom Functions:* Allow users to define their own functions within CS2MatchQL for specialized analysis.
** *Plugin System:* Consider a plugin system to enable easy addition of new data sources, events, or analysis modules.

*Key Snippets*

# Quadtree Node Structure:

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}type QuadtreeNode struct {
ID string `bson:"_id"`
ParentId string `bson:"parentId,omitempty"`
Level int `bson:"level"`
Bounds orb.Bound `bson:"bounds"`
IsLeaf bool `bson:"isLeaf"`
Objects []string `bson:"objects,omitempty"` // Object IDs if leaf node
Children []string `bson:"children,omitempty"` // Node IDs if internal node
}
{noformat}

# Example CS2MatchQL Query:

{noformat}match
round r
where r.number > 15
and exists (
event(Kill) as kill
where kill.weapon = 'AK-47'
and kill.killer.position inArea 'B-site'
)
stats.player('sound3k').kdr as sound3kKDR
{noformat}

# Example Quadtree Query Optimization:

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}// (Simplified example)
func queryQuadtree(qt *quadtree.Quadtree, area orb.Bound) []Object {
var results []Object
qt.Find(func(node *quadtree.Node) []orb.Pointer {
if !node.Bound().Intersects(area) {
return nil // No intersection, skip this branch
}
// ... (Collect objects from leaf nodes or recurse)
})
return results
}
{noformat}

*Deliverables*

# *CS2MatchQL Compiler (Go):* A Go implementation of the lexer, parser, semantic analyzer, query optimizer, and execution engine for CS2MatchQL.
# *Quadtree Implementation (Go):* A Go library for constructing, updating, and querying quadtrees within the ReplayAPI context.
# *ReplayAPI Endpoint:* A RESTful API endpoint for handling CS2MatchQL queries and returning results.
# *Documentation:* Comprehensive documentation for CS2MatchQL syntax, usage examples, and API endpoints.
# *Test Suite:* A robust test suite to ensure the correctness and performance of the implemented components.
 API, Analytics, Backend, CS:GO/CS:2, Filter, Filtering, GameEvent, Microservice, ReplayAPI, ResourceOwner, Search 12/jun/24 1:40 PM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development

Replay API REPL-72

[PARSER][Research*] Vision Cone (Angles by Tick)

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 12/jun/24 1:20 PM   12/jun/24 1:20 PM           0 1  

# *Accurate Representation:* Determine the most precise method for calculating vision cones within the CS game engine. This includes considering factors like player height, crouch status, view angles, and map geometry.
# *Performance Optimization:* Identify techniques to optimize the calculation and storage of vision cone data to ensure the backend processor can handle real-time analysis without significant performance impact.
# *Data Structure and Format:* Define an efficient data structure to represent vision cones in a way that is easily consumable by the overlay rendering engine.

*Research Methods*

# *Source Engine Deep Dive:*
#* Thoroughly investigate the Source Engine's internal rendering and visibility systems.
#* Explore the possibility of accessing relevant APIs or modifying the game engine to extract vision cone data directly.
#* Analyze demo files to understand how view angles and player positions are encoded and how they relate to actual visibility in-game.
# *3D Geometry and Raytracing:*
#* Study 3D geometry concepts like frustums and ray-triangle intersections.
#* Implement raytracing algorithms in Go to simulate lines of sight from the player's perspective and determine which parts of the map are visible.
#* Evaluate the performance impact of raytracing in a real-time context and explore optimization techniques (e.g., spatial partitioning, bounding volume hierarchies).
# *Open-Source Projects:*
#* Analyze existing open-source projects that deal with CS demo parsing or map analysis.
#* Investigate libraries or tools that provide functionality for calculating vision cones or similar visibility calculations.
#** *Examples:* libraries (for navigation mesh generation), {{csgo-demo-viewer}} (for demo visualization), and projects related to CS development.

*Potential Approaches*

# *Direct Source Engine Integration (Ideal):*
#* *Pros:* The most accurate method, as it leverages the game engine's own calculations for visibility.
#* *Cons:* Requires in-depth knowledge of the Source Engine, potential compatibility issues with future updates,and may be challenging to implement due to lack of official documentation.
# *Hybrid Approach (Recommended):*
#* *Pros:* Combines the accuracy of demo data with the flexibility of external calculations.
#* *Cons:* Requires careful calibration and testing to ensure consistency with the game engine's behavior.
# *Purely External Calculation (Backup):*
#* *Pros:* Most flexible approach, can be tailored to specific needs.
#* *Cons:* Potentially less accurate than using the game engine, requires meticulous implementation of 3D geometry and raytracing algorithms.

*Data Structure for Vision Cones*

A {{VisionCone}} struct could contain the following information:

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}type VisionCone struct {
PlayerName string
Origin common.Vector // Player's eye position
Direction common.Vector // View direction vector
HorizontalFOV float64 // Horizontal field of view (in degrees)
VerticalFOV float64 // Vertical field of view (in degrees)
Range float64 // Maximum view distance
Polygon []common.Vector // Vertices of the vision cone polygon (2D)
}
{noformat}

*Performance Optimizations*

* *Caching:* Store pre-calculated vision cone data for common scenarios (e.g., per player position on a map).
* *Spatial Indexing:* Use spatial data structures (e.g., quadtrees, R-trees) to efficiently query for objects within a vision cone.
* *Adaptive Resolution:* Adjust the level of detail of vision cone calculations based on the required accuracy and available processing power.

*Additional Considerations*

* *Player Height and Crouching:* Account for changes in player height and crouching status when calculating vision cones.
* *Grenade Effects:* Incorporate the effects of smoke grenades, which can obscure vision and create complex shapes that need to be accounted for.
* *Wall Penetration:* Determine if and how much bullets can penetrate walls to adjust visibility calculations accordingly.

*Deliverables*

# *Technical Report:* Summarizing the research findings, chosen approach, implementation details, and performance benchmarks.
# *Go Library:* A well-documented Go library for calculating and representing vision cones, integrated with the LeetGaming ReplayAPI.
# *Demo Implementation:* A working demo showcasing the integration of vision cone data with the overlay rendering engine.

*Timeline (Estimated)*

* Research and prototyping: 2 weeks
* Implementation and testing: 4 weeks
* Integration and optimization: 2 weeks 		12/jun/24 1:20 PM Em andamento

[PARSER] IN-DEPTH Performance Report (BattleLog)

Epic Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído psavelis Leet Gaming 10/jun/24 1:08 PM   03/jul/24 1:40 AM           0 1   *Core Fields*

* *Timestamp:* The exact time (in seconds) when an action occurred within the round.
* *Event Type:* A concise description of the action (e.g., Kill, Damage, Plant, Defuse, Buy, Grenade Throw, Position Update).
* {color:#36b37e}*Outcome****{color}*:* The result of the action (e.g., "HS" for Headshot, "FB" for Flashbang, "Kill", "Assist", "Damage","Plant", "Defuse").

*Advanced Action Details*

* *Frag Details:*
** Weapon Used
** Hit Group Breakdown
*** HitCount (grouped by hitbox)
*** {color:#36b37e}Hitbox: (Head, Chest, Stomach, Legs){color}
** {color:#36b37e}Distance{color} to Victim
** {color:#36b37e}Angle of Attack (Peeking Angle){color}
** Number of Enemies Alive (e.g., {color:#36b37e}1v1, 1v2{color})
** Frag/Kill Type ({color:#36b37e}Entry Frag, Closing Frag, Trade Frag){color}
** Assisting Players (if traded)
* *Damage Details:*
** Weapon Used
** Damage Dealt
** Hit Group
** Distance to Victim
** Armor Penetration
** Was Victim Flashed?
* *Utility Usage:*
** Grenade Type (Smoke, Flashbang, HE, Molotov/Incendiary)
** Grenade Effectiveness (Kills, Flashes, Smokes)
** Grenade Throw Type (Popflash, Jump Throw, Lineup)

*Tactical and Strategic Insights*

* {color:#36b37e}*Role:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Player's role in the round (Entry Fragger, Lurker, Support, Anchor).{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Decision Type:*{color}{color:#36b37e} The type of decision made (Aggressive, Defensive, Supportive, Utility-Based).{color}
* {color:#4c9aff}*Strategy Contribution ****:*{color}{color:#4c9aff} How the action contributed to the team's overall strategy (e.g., "Opened Bombsite","Delayed Attack", "Created Space").{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Impact Rating:*{color}{color:#36b37e} A numerical score (e.g., 1-5) indicating the {color}{color:#36b37e}*overall impact of the action on the round*{color}{color:#36b37e}.{color}

{color:#36b37e}*Additional Innovative Fields*{color}

* {color:#36b37e}*Clutch Factor:*{color}{color:#36b37e} A measure of how often a player wins crucial rounds when outnumbered.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Trade Potential:*{color}{color:#36b37e} An assessment of a player's ability to trade kills with opponents.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Map Awareness:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Analysis of a player's positioning and movement patterns relative to the map and objectives.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*Economic Impact:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Evaluation of how a player's actions affect their team's economy.{color}
* ❌{color:#ffc400} {color}{color:#ffc400}*Communication:*{color}{color:#ffc400} A log of voice communications or chat messages related to the player's actions{color}{color:#36b37e}.{color}
{color:#ff5630}(THIS REQUIRES PLAYER’S CONSENT OVER DATA PROCESSING AND ALSO ANOTHER CONSENT IF IT NEEDS TO GO PUBLIC){color}

{color:#36b37e}*Example Round Report Entries*{color}

* {color:#36b37e}*0:15:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Kill (AK-47, HS) 1 enemy. Entry frag, {color}{color:#4c9aff}aggressive peek mid{color}{color:#36b37e}.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*0:30:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Flash (Popflash) 0:1 x2 enemies.{color}{color:#4c9aff} Opened A-site for execute.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*1:00:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Damage (AWP, 98) Chest. Long-range pick, {color}{color:#4c9aff}traded with support player.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*1:25:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Plant (B-site). {color}{color:#4c9aff}Secured bombsite after successful split.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*1:45:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Kill (USP-S) 1 enemy. Clutch 1v1, {color}{color:#4c9aff}defused bomb under pressure{color}{color:#36b37e}.{color}

*Benefits of Enhanced Round Reports*

* {color:#36b37e}*Granular Analysis:*{color}{color:#36b37e} Provides a highly detailed breakdown of individual actions and their context within the round.{color}
* {color:#36b37e}*AI-Free, Precise Tactical Insights *:*{color} Offers actionable feedback on decision-making, positioning, and strategic choices.
* *Performance Evaluation:* Enables objective assessment of individual and team performance.
* {color:#4c9aff}*Coaching and Training*{color}*:* Facilitates targeted coaching and training based on identified strengths and weaknesses. 		API, Analytics, Backend, CS:GO/CS:2, GameEvent, ML, ReplayAPI, Search, UX 10/jun/24 1:08 PM Em andamento orange

Replay API REPL-69

EPIC: CS2MatchQL/CS2QL R (Language & Compiler)

Epic Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/jun/24 6:24 PM   07/jun/24 6:51 PM           0 1   *Overall Architecture*

The architecture will follow a classic compiler pipeline:

# *Lexical Analysis (Lexer):* Breaks down the input query into tokens (keywords, identifiers, operators, literals).
# *Syntax Analysis (Parser):* Constructs an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) from the tokens, representing the query's structure.
# *Semantic Analysis:* Validates the AST, performs type checking, and resolves references.
# *Optimization (Optional):* Transforms the AST to improve query performance.
# *Code Generation:* Generates an executable representation of the query (e.g., MongoDB aggregation pipeline).

*Framework and Library Choices*

* *Lexer & Parser:*
** *Golex:* A powerful lexical analyzer generator for Go. It allows you to define regular expressions for tokens and generates efficient code to recognize them.
** *Goparser:* A versatile parser generator for Go. You can define the grammar of CS2MatchQL using BNF (Backus-Naur Form) or EBNF (Extended BNF), and Goparser will generate a parser that can construct the AST.
* *Abstract Syntax Tree (AST):*
** *Go AST Library:* Leverage the standard Go AST library ({{go/ast}}) to define the structure of the AST nodes.This allows you to easily manipulate and traverse the AST during semantic analysis and code generation.
* *Semantic Analysis:*
** *Go's Type System:* Utilize Go's static type system to enforce type safety and catch errors during compilation. Define custom types for different CS2MatchQL constructs (events, states, operators) and check for type compatibility.
** *Symbol Table:* Maintain a symbol table to track variable declarations and scope. This is essential for resolving references and ensuring that variables are used correctly.
* *Code Generation:*
** *MongoDB Driver:* Use the official MongoDB Go driver ({{mongo-go-driver}}) to construct MongoDB aggregation pipelines from the AST.
* *Additional Libraries:*
** *Error Handling:* Consider using a library like {{pkg/errors}} for better error handling and propagation.
** *Logging:* Use a logging framework like {{logrus}} or {{zap}} for debugging and monitoring.
** *Testing:* Write comprehensive unit and integration tests using a framework like {{testify}} to ensure the correctness of the compiler.

*Detailed Implementation*

# *Lexer (Golex):*
#* Define regular expressions for CS2MatchQL tokens (keywords, identifiers, operators, literals).
#* Use Golex to generate the lexer code.
# *Parser (Goparser):*
#* Define the CS2MatchQL grammar using BNF or EBNF.
#* Use Goparser to generate the parser code.
#* Construct the AST based on the parsed tokens.
# *Semantic Analysis:*
#* Validate the AST to ensure it adheres to the language's rules.
#* Perform type checking on expressions and assignments.
#* Resolve references to variables and functions.
# *Optimization (Optional):*
#* Identify redundant calculations or conditions.
#* Rearrange expressions to improve efficiency.
#* Consider using caching mechanisms for frequently used queries.
# *Code Generation (MongoDB Aggregation):*
#* Traverse the AST and translate it into a MongoDB aggregation pipeline.
#* Use the MongoDB Go driver to construct and execute the aggregation pipeline.
#* Handle errors gracefully and provide informative error messages.

*Example: Parsing a Simple Query*

{noformat}Go{noformat}

{noformat}// (Simplified example)
query := "match round 15 where event(Kill) and killer.name = 'sound'"
lexer := NewLexer(query)
parser := NewParser()

// Parse the query
ast, err := parser.Parse(lexer)
// ... (Handle errors)

// Analyze and optimize the AST
// ...

// Generate MongoDB query
mongoQuery := generateMongoDBQuery(ast)
// ...
{noformat}

*Testing and Validation*

* *Unit Tests:* Write unit tests for each component (lexer, parser, analyzer, code generator) to ensure they function correctly in isolation.
* *Integration Tests:* Test the entire compiler pipeline with various valid and invalid queries.
* *Performance Tests:* Measure the performance of the compiler with large and complex queries.
* *Fuzz Testing:* Use fuzz testing to discover potential vulnerabilities and edge cases.

*Additional Considerations*

* *Error Reporting:* Design a user-friendly error reporting mechanism that provides clear and actionable feedback to users.
* *IDE Integration:* Explore creating language plugins for popular IDEs (e.g., VSCode) to provide syntax highlighting, code completion, and error checking for CS2MatchQL.
* *Documentation:* Maintain comprehensive documentation that includes the language specification, tutorials, examples, and API references.

h1. {color:#36b37e}*Ubiquitous Language (draft v1)*{color}

*General Gameplay*

* *Round:* A single period of play within a match.
* *Half:* One of two halves in a match, typically 15 rounds each.
* *Side:* The team a player is on (T or Counter-T).
* *Bombsite (or Site):* The designated areas (A and B) where Ts can plant the bomb.
* *Spawn:* The starting area for each team.
* *Buy Time/Freeze Time:* The initial phases of a round where players can purchase weapons and equipment.

*Weapons and Equipment*

* *AWP:* The most powerful sniper rifle in the game.
* *Rifle:* Primary long-range weapon (e.g., AK-47, M4A4).
* *SMG:* Submachine gun, good for close-quarters combat (e.g., MP9, MAC-10).
* *Pistol:* Sidearm used in early rounds or for quick kills (e.g., USP-S, Glock-18).
* *Utility:* Non-lethal equipment (e.g., grenades, flashbangs, smoke grenades, molotovs/incendiaries).
* *Kevlar/Armor:* Protective gear that reduces damage.
* *Helmet:* Head protection that reduces headshot damage.
* *Defuse Kit:* A tool that allows Counter-Ts to defuse the bomb faster.

*Player Actions*

* *Frag:* A kill.
* *Headshot:* A kill with a bullet to the head.
* *Kill:* Eliminating an enemy player.
* *Assist:* Helping a teammate get a kill (e.g., by damaging the enemy).
* *Clutch:* Winning a round despite being outnumbered.
* *Ace:* Killing all five members of the enemy team in a single round.
* *Entry Frag:* The first kill in a round, typically secured by the player entering a bombsite first.
* *Retake:* Counter-Ts retaking control of a bombsite after the bomb has been planted.
* *Rotate:* A team moving from one area of the map to another.
* *Peek:* Briefly exposing oneself from cover to gather information or take a shot.
* *Boost:* One player crouching to allow another to jump on their head for a height advantage.

*Team Strategies*

* *Execute:* A coordinated attack on a bombsite.
* *Default:* A standard setup where players hold specific positions on the map.
* *Rush:* A fast, aggressive attack on a bombsite.
* *Split:* Dividing the team to attack multiple areas simultaneously.
* *Fake:* A deceptive maneuver to distract the enemy team.
* *Eco:* A round where a team buys minimal or no equipment to save money.
* *Force Buy:* A round where a team spends most of its money on weapons and equipment despite having low funds.

*Advanced Terms*

* *Peeker's Advantage:* The advantage a player has when peeking around a corner due to network latency and game mechanics.
* *Crosshair Placement:* The position of a player's crosshair in anticipation of an enemy.
* *Spray Pattern:* The pattern in which bullets spread when firing a weapon in automatic mode.
* *Recoil Control:* The technique of managing a weapon's recoil to maintain accuracy.
* *Utility Usage:* The strategic deployment of grenades and other non-lethal equipment.

*Additional Terms*

* *Demo:* A recording of a match that can be reviewed.
* *Config:* A player's personalized game settings.
* *MM/Matchmaking:* The automated system for finding online matches.
* *Rank:* A player's competitive skill rating.
* *Overtime:* Additional rounds played if a match ends in a tie.

*General Calls*

* *Default:* Establishing a standard setup, with players holding specific positions on the map.
* *Slow:* A cautious approach, prioritizing information gathering and map control.
* *Fast:* An aggressive push onto a bombsite or area of the map.
* *Eco:* A round where the team buys minimal equipment to save money.
* *Force Buy:* A round where the team spends most of its money despite having low funds.
* *Save:* A round where the team intentionally avoids engaging in combat to preserve weapons for the next round.

*T-Side Calls*

* *Execute A/B:* A coordinated attack on a specific bombsite.
* *Split A/B:* Dividing the team to attack both bombsites simultaneously.
* *Late Execute:* Delaying the attack until later in the round to catch the defenders off guard.
* *Fake A/B:* A deceptive maneuver to make the defenders think you're attacking one site while actually hitting the other.
* *Contact:* Push forward and engage the enemy to gather information.
* *Stack A/B:* Focusing all players on a single bombsite for a concentrated attack.

*Counter-T-Side Calls*

* *Hold A/B:* Defending a specific bombsite.
* *Rotate A/B:* Moving players from one bombsite to another to counter the T attack.
* *Aggressive A/B:* Pushing out from a bombsite to actively hunt for Ts.
* *Stack A/B:* Focusing all players on a single bombsite for a strong defense.
* *Bait:* Intentionally leaving a bombsite vulnerable to lure the Ts into a trap.
* *Retake:* Reclaiming a bombsite after it has been planted.

*Additional Calls (More Specific)*

* *Boost Me (Position):* Requesting a boost to a specific location.
* *Flash (Position):* Asking a teammate to throw a flashbang at a specific location.
* *Smoke (Position):* Requesting a smoke grenade to be thrown at a specific location.
* *Molly (Position):* Requesting a molotov or incendiary grenade to be thrown at a specific location.
* *Watch (Position):* Asking a teammate to keep an eye on a specific area.
* *Lurker (Position):* Assigning a player to a flanking or isolated position.
* *Second Mid/Second A/Second B:* Asking for a teammate to provide additional support to a specific area.

*Examples of Calls*

* "Default B, slow!"
* "Execute A on my go!"
* "Split A, two on B!"
* "Fake B, hit A on my call!"
* "Eco, save!"
* "Force buy, full A!"
* "Hold B, aggressive CT!"
* "Rotate to A, one stays on B!"
* "Bait B, stack A!"
* "Retake A, slow and steady!"

{color:#36b37e}*Important Note:*{color}

{color:#36b37e}The specific calls and strategies used can vary greatly depending on the map, team composition, and individual playstyles.{color}

{color:#36b37e}Effective communication and coordination are crucial for executing these calls successfully.{color} 		07/jun/24 6:24 PM Em andamento green
0|i000zr: Nenhum
Replay API REPL-68

[Spike][Brainstorm] CS2QL Reimagined (CS2MatchQL)

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) psavelis Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/jun/24 4:30 PM   07/jun/24 4:58 PM           0 1   DRAFT!!

*Philosophy*

CS2MatchQL is designed to empower analysts, coaches, and enthusiasts to deeply understand the intricacies of CS:2 matches. It focuses on:

* *State Awareness:* Tracks the evolving state of the game (e.g., player positions, weapon states, bomb status) for context-rich queries.
* *Round-Based Analysis:* Easily isolate specific rounds or phases within a round for detailed analysis.
* *Statistical Insights:* Provides built-in functions to calculate essential stats (K/D ratios, ADR, economic trends).
* *Pattern Recognition:* Identifies recurring strategic patterns within matches (e.g., executes, retakes, rotations).

*Keywords and Structure*

* {{match}}: The root of every query, defining the scope of the match being analyzed.
* {{round}}: Narrows the scope to a specific round number or a range of rounds.
* {{event}}: Filters for specific game events (e.g., {{Kill}}, {{Plant}}, {{Buy}}, {{PositionUpdate}}).
* {{state}}: Queries the game state at a specific time or in relation to an event.
* {{stats}}: Calculates aggregated statistics for players, teams, or across the match.

*Intelligent Snippets*

# Identifying Clutch Situations:

{noformat}match
where round.phase = 'PostPlant'
and event(Kill)
and state.ctAlive = 1
and state.tAlive <= 2
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Pinpoints clutch scenarios where a CT player eliminates multiple Ts in a post-plant situation.

# Analyzing Economy Impact:

{noformat}match round 15
stats.team('T').averageEquipmentValue
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Reveals the average equipment value of the T side in round 15, aiding in economic analysis.

# Tracking Player Movement:

{noformat}match
event(PositionUpdate) as pos1,
event(PositionUpdate) as pos2
where pos1.player = 'sound'
and pos2.player = 'sound'
and pos2.time - pos1.time <= 5
return pos1.position, pos2.position
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Traces the movement of a specific player ({{sound}}) within a 5-second window, offering insights into positioning and rotations.

# Detecting Specific Strategies:

{noformat}match round 2
where event(SmokeStart) as smoke1,
event(SmokeStart) as smoke2,
event(FlashbangStart) as flash
where smoke1.position ~ 'A-site'
and smoke2.position ~ 'A-site'
and flash.position ~ 'A-site'
and flash.time - smoke1.time <= 2
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Identifies a potential execute strategy on A site in round 2, marked by the use of multiple smokes and a flashbang in quick succession.

# Evaluating Player Performance:

{noformat}match
stats.player('sh__x').kdr,
stats.player('sh__x').adr,
stats.player('sh__x').kast
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Provides a comprehensive overview of a player's performance throughout the match, including K/D ratio,ADR, and KAST (percentage of rounds with a kill, assist, survival, or traded death).

*Additional Features (Future)*

* *Event Sequencing:* Express complex patterns involving sequences of events.
* *State Comparison:* Compare game states across different rounds or moments.
* *Predictive Analysis:* Leverage machine learning to predict outcomes or suggest optimal strategies based on historical data.
* *Visualization Integration:* Seamlessly integrate with visualization tools to display query results as interactive charts or heatmaps.

Snippets targeting a wider range of tactical and strategic insights:

# Identifying Fake A Execute B:

{noformat}match
round r
where (
// Early aggression towards A
exists (
event(SmokeStart) as aSmoke,
event(GrenadeStart) as aGrenade
where aSmoke.position ~ 'A-site'
and aGrenade.position ~ 'A-site'
and aSmoke.time < r.halfTime
and aGrenade.time < r.halfTime
)
// AND a rotation to B site later in the round
and exists (
event(BombPlant) as plant
where plant.position ~ 'B-site'
)
)
{noformat}

*Benefit:* Detects rounds where Ts show early aggression on A, only to rotate and plant the bomb on B.

# Identifying Lurker Role:

{noformat}match
event(Kill) as kill
where exists (
state.player(kill.killer).position as pos
where pos ~ 'Off-Angles' or pos ~ 'Flank'
)
{noformat}

*Benefit:* Finds kills made from off-angles or flanking positions, indicative of a lurker's playstyle.

# Identifying Eco/Half Buy/Full Buy Rounds:

{noformat}match round r
stats.team('T').averageEquipmentValue as tEquip
stats.team('CT').averageEquipmentValue as ctEquip
where tEquip < 1000 // Eco
or (tEquip >= 1000 and tEquip < 4000) // Half buy
or (tEquip >= 4000) // Full buy
{noformat}

*Benefit:* Classifies rounds based on the average equipment value of each team, revealing their economic state.

# Team Weapon Power Analysis:

{noformat}match round r
stats.team('CT').weaponBreakdown as ctWeapons
where ctWeapons['AWP'] >= 3
{noformat}

*Benefit:* Identifies rounds where the CT side had a significant AWP presence (3 or more), influencing their defensive strategy.

# Identifying Flick Shots:

{noformat}match
event(Kill) as kill
where kill.aimPunchAngle > 5
{noformat}

*Benefit:* Detects kills where the player's crosshair moved significantly after firing the shot, suggesting a flick shot.

*Additional Intelligent Snippets:*

* *Identifying Retake Strategies:* Look for patterns of utility usage (smokes, flashes) followed by coordinated pushes onto a site after a bomb plant.
* *Entry Fragger Analysis:* Find players with high first-kill percentages and analyze their weapon choices and positions.
* *Map Control Patterns:* Track the movement of players across the map to identify areas of dominant control or frequent rotations.
* *Round Outcome Prediction:* Utilize machine learning models to predict round outcomes based on early-round events (e.g., pistol round wins, first blood)

Snippets focused on aim, trajectories, and ninja defuses:

*Aim-Related Snippets*

# *Identifying Headshots:*
{noformat}match
event(Kill) as kill
where kill.hitgroup = 'head'
{noformat}
#* *Benefit:* Finds all kills that were headshots.
# *Analyzing First Bullet Accuracy (FBA):*
{noformat}match
event(Damage) as damage
where damage.isHit
and damage.isFirstBullet
stats.average(damage.hitgroupDistance) as avgDistance
{noformat}
#* *Benefit:* Calculates the average distance of the first bullet hit for all damage events, giving insights into a player's initial shot accuracy.
# *Detecting Spray Control:*
{noformat}match
event(Damage) as d1,
event(Damage) as d2,
event(Damage) as d3
where d1.attacker = d2.attacker = d3.attacker
and d2.time - d1.time <= 1 // Adjust time window as needed
and d3.time - d1.time <= 1
stats.average(d1.sprayDeviation, d2.sprayDeviation, d3.sprayDeviation) as avgSprayDeviation
{noformat}
#* *Benefit:* Calculates the average spray deviation across three consecutive shots by the same player, giving insights into their spray control abilities.

*Trajectory-Related Snippets*

# *Analyzing Grenade Throws:*
{noformat}match
event(GrenadeStart) as grenade
where grenade.grenadeType = 'smoke'
and grenade.position ~ 'Mid Doors'
{noformat}
#* *Benefit:* Finds all smoke grenades thrown near "Mid Doors." Modify the {{grenadeType}} and {{position}} to target other grenade types or locations.
# *Tracking Bullet Trajectories:*
{noformat}match
event(Damage) as damage
return damage.startPosition, damage.endPosition
{noformat}
#* *Benefit:* Extracts the start and end positions of every bullet that hits a player, allowing for trajectory analysis and visualization.

*Ninja Defuse Snippet*

{noformat}match
event(BombDefuseStart) as defuseStart,
event(BombDefuseEnd) as defuseEnd
where defuseEnd.time - defuseStart.time < 3 // Typical defuse time is 5 seconds
and state.tAlive >= 2 // At least 2 Ts alive during defuse
{noformat}

* *Benefit:* Identifies defuses completed very quickly while the defuser was under pressure (Ts still alive).

*Advanced Snippets (Potential Future Enhancements)*

* *Aim Duel Analysis:* Analyze sequences of damage events between two specific players to assess their aim duel performance.

* *Spray Pattern Visualization:* Combine trajectory data with map layouts to visualize spray patterns on the map.
* *Grenade Effectiveness:* Track the impact of grenades (kills, flashes, smokes) to evaluate their effectiveness.
* *Crosshair Placement:* Analyze crosshair placement data (if available) to assess a player's aiming habits and pre-aiming tendencies.

 API, Backend, CS:GO/CS:2, Filter, Filtering, GameEvent, Search 07/jun/24 4:30 PM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development
0|i000zj: Nenhum
Replay API REPL-67

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/jun/24 12:37 PM   07/jun/24 12:37 PM           0 1   07/jun/24 12:37 PM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development

Tarefa Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 07/jun/24 10:14 AM   07/jun/24 10:14 AM           0 1   07/jun/24 10:14 AM Em andamento EPIC: Replay API Core Development

EPIC: Professional CS Roles (Beyond Players & Teams) [DRAFT!!]

Epic Discovery & Refinement Medium Não resolvido(s) Não atribuído Leet Gaming Leet Gaming 30/mai/24 11:41 AM   30/mai/24 11:41 AM           0 1   [DRAFT] (main idea here is to, at same time, include and give more professional visibility to the Staff working in the background beyond players and teams, provide up-to-date, curated information about their work, show when they are online, providing visibility and granting a space for these professionals to foster into the discussions, allowing them to make more connections and create quality contributions for the community)

* *Coaches:* Often former professional players, coaches provide strategic guidance, analyze opponents, and help players develop their skills.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Coach, Strategic Analyst
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/coaches/[coach_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/teams/[team_id]/coach}} (Team-Specific)
*** {{/matches/[match_id]/coaches}} (Match Analysis)
*** {{/search?role=coach}} (Search)
* *Analysts:* Dive deep into match data, statistics, and trends to provide insights for teams and the wider community.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Analyst, Data Scientist
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/analysts/[analyst_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/teams/[team_id]/analyst}} (Team-Specific)
*** {{/matches/[match_id]/analysis}} (Match Analysis)
*** {{/search?role=analyst}} (Search)
* *Casters/Commentators:* The voices of CS, providing live commentary and analysis during matches, enhancing the viewing experience for fans.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Caster, Commentator, Play-by-Play Commentator, Color Commentator
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/casters/[caster_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/matches/[match_id]/cast}} (Live or Recorded Cast)
*** {{/search?role=caster}} (Search)
* *Hosts/Presenters:* Introduce matches, segments, and conduct interviews, bringing personality and engagement to broadcasts.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Host, Presenter, Desk Host
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/hosts/[host_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/events/[event_id]/host}} (Event-Specific)
*** {{/search?role=host}} (Search)
* *Observers:* Control the in-game camera during live broadcasts, ensuring viewers see the most important action.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Observer, GOTV (Game Observer)
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:* (Less common to have individual observer profiles)
*** {{/matches/[match_id]/observers}} (List of Observers for a Match)
* *Production Crew:* The behind-the-scenes team responsible for the technical aspects of broadcasts, including video, audio, and graphics.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Producer, Director, Technical Director, Replay Operator, etc.
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:* (Less common to have individual profiles)
*** {{/events/[event_id]/production}} (List of Crew for an Event)
* *Tournament Organizers:* The companies or individuals responsible for planning and executing CS tournaments.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Tournament Organizer (TO)
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/tournament-organizers/[organizer_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/events/[event_id]/organizer}} (Event-Specific)
*** {{/search?role=organizer}} (Search)
* *Journalists/Content Creators:* Individuals who write articles, produce videos, or create other content about the CS scene.
** *Preferred Terminology:* Journalist, Content Creator, Esports Writer, Video Producer
** *LeetGaming Pro Routes:*
*** {{/journalists/[journalist_id]}} (Profile)
*** {{/news/[article_id]}} (News Article)
*** {{/videos/[video_id]}} (Video Content)
*** {{/search?role=journalist}} (Search)

*Community Terminology*

In the CS community, terms like "IGL" (In-Game Leader), "Lurker," "Rifler," "AWPer," etc., refer to specific player roles within a team. While important, they don't typically warrant separate profiles on a platform like LeetGaming Pro.

*Additional Tips for LeetGaming Pro*

* *Interviews and Features:* Conduct interviews with coaches, analysts, casters, and other professionals to showcase their insights and personalities.
* *Highlight Reels:* Create highlight reels showcasing the best plays from specific roles (e.g., "Top 10 strategic Plays").
* *Community Forums:* Allow fans to discuss and debate the contributions of different roles in the scene. 		30/mai/24 11:41 AM Em andamento purple
